course.name: Complete JavaScript (Browser, Node, TS)
course.description: From absolute beginner to advanced full-stack developer. Covers standard JS, Node.js backend, and TypeScript.

lessons.title: Variables: let, const, and var
objectives: Understand variables as labeled containers for data
Distinguish between let (reassignable) and const (immutable binding)
Know why 'var' is generally avoided in modern JS

explanations: Think of variables as labeled boxes where you can store information to use later.
In modern JavaScript, we primarily use two labels: 'const' for boxes whose contents won't be completely swapped out, and 'let' for boxes that might need new contents later.
We avoid the older label 'var' because it behaves in confusing ways regarding where it can be accessed (scoping).

oralQuestions.prompt: If you're creating a variable for someone's date of birth, which keyword should you use and why?
I've declared 'const score = 0'. What happens if I later try to do 'score = score + 1'?

hints: Read the error message carefully: 'Assignment to constant variable'.
If a value needs to change over time, 'const' might be too restrictive.

exercises.prompt: Declare a 'const' variable called 'myname' with your name as a string, and a 'let' variable called 'myage' with a number.

questions.prompt: Which declaration should be your default choice in modern JS?
What will this output? let a = 5; let b = a; a = 10; console.log(b);

lessons.title: Data Types & typeof
objectives: Identify primitive types: string, number, boolean, null, undefined
Use the 'typeof' operator to inspect values

explanations: In JavaScript, every value has a 'type'. It's like knowing if something is a text, a number, or a true/false switch.
We can ask JavaScript what type something is by using the 'typeof' operator before the value.

oralQuestions.prompt: What do you think 'typeof 3.14' will return?
What's the difference between 'undefined' and 'null' conceptually?

hints: Look closely at the quotes around 25.
Check the type of 'age' using typeof.
When you add a number to a string, JavaScript sticks them together instead of doing math.

exercises.prompt: Create a variable 'isDone' and set it to a boolean value. Log its type.

lessons.title: Loops: Iteration Basics
objectives: Understand the purpose of loops (repeating tasks)
Master the 3 parts of a 'for' loop: init, condition, increment

explanations: Loops let us repeat an action without writing the same code over and over.
A 'for' loop is like a track: you start at a spot (initialization), you keep running as long as a rule is met (condition), and you take a step each time (increment).

oralQuestions.prompt: If I change the condition to 'i < 5' instead of 'i <= 5', what's the last number it will log?
How would you change the loop to count DOWN from 10 to 1?

hints: Look at the middle part, the condition: i > 5.
What is the initial value of 'i'?
Is 1 greater than 5? The loop only runs if true.

exercises.prompt: Write a for loop that logs only EVEN numbers from 0 to 10.
